Review Text: Surrounded by giant boulders, this temple is a low-key and intriguing site. You'll climb past some caves with reclining Buddhas and when you continue to climb to the main rock, you'll find a huge golden Buddha on the hillside.
A very nice cave temple complex where there are several caves with Bhoeda statues in addition there is a small museum. Definitely worth making a stop here

Review Title: explore Sri Lanka with GLITTER TRAVELS (PVT) LTD
Review Text: Matale Aluvihare is a significant historical and religious site located in Matale, a town in central Sri Lanka, about 25 kilometers from Kandy. The Aluvihare rock temple is an important Buddhist temple with deep historical roots, especially known for its connection to the preservation of Buddhist scriptures.
The climb is challenging but absolutely feasible and when you get to the temple I am sure you will be happy and satisfied. It is definitely a temple to see and enjoy.

I love this template. It is a hidden gem in Sri Lanka. Not sure why more tourists don't visit. This temple has cultural significance as it is the place Tripitakaya was transcribed on palm leaves (housed in the library on site).

Aluvihare Rock Temple or Matale Aluvihare is one of the most important Buddhist temples near Matale city centre. This is the place where the Pali Canon was first written. There are some caves and recently added viharaya, pagoda and museums. Museums have a little collection of ancient artefacts. It seems the temple is overlooked even amidst its importance. I feel its old pride has been taken away by modern buildings. It has high cultural, historical and educational values. Please wear full clothes. Shorts and skinnies are not allowed. The Great King Walagamba had built this during the 03rd century BC.

A beautiful statue on a rock on the top of the hill which is 400-500m away from Aluvihara Cave Temple. You may witness a bird-eye view of Matale area along with a picturesque view of a group of mountains. The road is good enogh to get closer to the statue by a vehicle and then have to walk around 100m to enter to the premises. Never miss to visit this place
Really worth exploring Enchanting and really spectacular and free Views are also majestic and a great intro into cave temple rock religious history
ideal place for meditation. best to visit early morning. and evening. great historical and valuable place.

Review Title: Underwhelming after visiting Dambulla Golden Cave Temple
Review Text: This is another cave temple in between Dambulla and Kandy, but smaller scale as compared to Dambulla Golden Cave Temple and less tourists here. Lower entrance fee of LKR300 per person, but underwhelming effect as compared to Dambulla Golden Temple. It would be interesting if visiting this temple first, followed by Dambulla Golden Temple for the build up/ elevation effect of the overall impression. Some of the wall paintings focus on the after life depiction (which we didn’t take picture), such as punishment in hell (after life) which made us rather uncomfortable level. Hence, it was an average impression/ experience for us, especially after visiting Dambulla Golden Temple.

This is a really good place to go and see some of the history of Buddhism if you are in the Dambulla /Aluvihare Region .Most people only come and stand outside and look at the statue on the hill ...but it is worth the time to go and look inside and it is Free so no need to pay to go in .

Around 160 MT high rock temple situated in natural caves having reclining Buddha statues. Caves are having paintings on walls & ceilings of  different eras crafted by different kings. Excellent place to visit. It takes around 1 hr to climb and back.
The paintings in the caves are really graphic and I actually really liked them. Would not suggest bringing kids
This is a traditional and very important temple in sri lanka.its very important to buddhism.i visit with my family in poya day.its was crowded.its a rock ancient rock temple.
Aluvihara Rock Cave Temple is not to be missed while in Sri Lanka.  It is amazing to see all the work that was done so long ago.  The details and the colors are fantastic.

Many stairs but worth the effort. Temple carved from the rock up to 5 different caves / temples. A little dark in the temples but understandable. Trip Advisor please remove Buddha photo from your posting.

We had a guided tour, and seen 4 of the 5 caves (one was being restored). You need to cover up boys knees (you can get a sarong there). Depending on the time you might have a small wait due to ceremony time (only 15 mins). It's amazing to think that this guy impacted so many people!
we visit this temple to see the amazing buddha statues and the history this temple has. well preserved clay and rock statues.

This is located in the Matale town, around 30 km north of Kandy. This is where the Tripiṭaka (philosophical doctrines of Buddhism) was  transcribed.  This is belongs to  3rd Century B.C. This is a very nice cave temple with wonderful arts. Since this is a temple it is better to visit this place with suitable attire (not short and sleeveless).

Just 3km from Mathale town. This was build in 3rd century  B.C. This place known as the first to write Buddhisum (documentation). Those are writen on leaves of plam trees. There are many monastery caves and has beautiful buddha's stratues. The caves walls are enriched with old arts. These caves looks a small version of Dambulla cave temple. There is a small museum next to caves so you can get understand how older days monks writen letters on tree leaves.

Ancient  cave  temple( Aluviharaya cave temple) in Sri Lanka. This   rock-cave temple is a sacred Buddhist temple located in Aluvihara, on the road from Dambulla to Matale. Surrounded by hills. lovely place to visit and lot more to see.
Ancient temple. This temple is enriched with splendid wall arts. It stands in a beautiful and serene atmosphere.  But security is low.

Hi I would like to say this is teample awesome place to visit ....an one more thing to happy this my home town also ...even I am proud to be home town ...any one want to visit pls let me know I will be there an will explain all about history ....if u interesting ...✌️❤️🙏🕉️🇱🇰🇱🇰🇱🇰🇱🇰. Much love yaaaa a ...stay with Rasta Neel ....
this is a nice place to visit, with the Rock Temple being the main attraction, very nice and cool on a hot day
These rock temples have been used by Buddhist monks as their dwelling places in ancient Sri Lanka. A must visit place for those interested in caves.

You can see the Temple & Buddha statue from the main road, where the entry point has an impressive elephant frieze. This site is very important in the Buddhists culture as the place where the first written records of Buddhism were made

We visited this temple as a day trip from Kandy, we didn't want to travel all the way to Dambulla so this was a perfect alternative. It may be smaller but it's really beautiful and generally less crowded, we actually could see the main cave on our own. We paid 300 rupees for the caves, then a man wanted more "dollars" to enter the cave with the "sins of sri lanka" but we didn't want to pay more so we didn't visit that one. I honestly don't know if it was actually included in the entrance fee and he was just scamming us. Complete you visit going up the hill to the gold buddha

Very well worth a visit here, it's much much quieter than any of the other Temples we visited and apart from my wife and I, our guide  and driver we only encountered one other couple here. There's a lot to see on different levels, and some of the paintings are very different from anything we've seen anywhere else. The visions of hell are just that! Lovely carvings around doorways and many Buddhas to admire. The small museum is worth a visit too and the curator gave us a demonstration of the writing techniques used in the old palm leaf manuscripts. Highly recommend a visit here, but ensure you dress appropriately for a religious site.

The walk to the top is easier on the slope than the steps. Stopping off seats for those less fit. Worth the effort as the rocks and caves that host the temples are spectacular. The paintings inside and the history of their origin make this a great visit. Prepare to cover up of course and the heat can be meltingly awful but still worth it. Local guide spoke good English , was knowledgeable and although it was very busy found our group of 8 great viewing spots.
Ancient Temple and monastery to visit for who is interested in the Buddhist religion and its history in Shri-Lanka. The museum explains the re-writing of books destroyed during the Dutch presence.

These caves were carved out of the granite rocks.  Once you have climbed a large staircase there are fantastic views over the surrounding countryside. Caves have some amazing wall paintings - particularly graphic are the pictures of Hell. Now a UNESCO Heritage site these caves give a massive insight into life 2000 years ago.
Not all temples are the same and this one holds a few dark surprises in its wall etchings!  Definitely worth a visit.
this is the place where holy "canon"or "thripitakaya" fore the first time.it was happen over 1500 years ago

Aluvihare cave temple is an ancient temple located in Matale alongside Matale Dambulla road. It's quite an important place not only given the cave atmosphere but also the process of literature which brought 'Thripitakaya' of Buddhism's three volumes of teaching in to scripts. The first of it's kind in written. The materials used and the process done are very interesting facts to learn.
This situated near to Matale town and it is a important religious place for Buddhists. There you can see rock caves and ancient paintings of great culture

The history of Aluvihare Rock Temple begins with the reign of King Devanampiyatissa, in the 3rd century BC. The temple has many caves with ancient inscriptions, newish ceiling paintings and impressive statues and images of Buddha. The main cave contains a large reclining statue of Buddha, together with standing and seated images, while in the entrance-way of another cave with a reclining statue of Buddha there are some strange and terrifying depictions of the hellish afterlife that awaits people who commits sins - images that I've seen in Christian churches, but never in a Buddhist temple before. There were no other tourists at the time of our visit, it was quiet and we took our time.. It's an interesting place, very much worth your visit....

Located in Matale, this temple is an ancient Buddhist heritage site. It is a historic place of worship where the Thripitaka (The essential Buddhist script) has been written by a congregate of elite Buddhist monks. The rock cave is full of ancient statues and arts while an exhibition by the side illustrates the types of punishments that the Kings used to put convicted persons under back in the day.

Temple situated 32 km north of Kandy. It's a small cave cave temple but highly significant to the history of Buddhism. During the 1st century BCE, the island was ravaged by anarchy and starvation, and the very survival of Buddhism was threatened. This was because at the time, its teachings were orally transmitted by monks, and many had died or left the island. Some of the surviving monks then decided to commit the whole of the Thripitaka to writing. The forth Buddhist council was convened and as  a result, it was written down for the first time in the island's history. In this way, the teachings were preserved in it's original form and Buddhism survived this difficult period. The momentous event was held at the Aluvihara cave temple, originally known as the Aloka Lena , or "Cave of Light".
We were not very impressed by this site especially the murals of the realms of hell. Have never seen anything like this in a Buddhist temple. Weird! Waste of time on our opinion.
sometimes you feel not another temple!! this was so different well worth the walk the buddhas are superb and the way the temple has been created is astonishing
You can see the ancient views in this temple , it's really worth to visit to see how naturally located all those rocks and to see the historical things.

Aluvihare Rock Temple was the historic location where the Buddha's teachings was first written down completely in text on ola (palm) leaves. This was done  In the 1st Century B.C., during King Walagamba's time.

Our tour itinerary did not have a visit to Dambulla caves scheduled but our driver eased this visit in en route so we got a taster. A quick side trip with a compact, but still dramatic setting and colourful caves. The depiction of hell was interesting! Note you can drive right up to the entrance with a minibus.

Our Homestay in Kandy recommended this Temple as a stopover enroute from Dambulla to Kandy. We are definitely glad she did. Entry was LKR250. It was quiet when we were there. Loved the atmosphere and setting of this temple. Much smaller and less touristy than the Dambulla one.

It is a very short walk up one flight of stairs to the cave temple complex, takes about 5 minutes from the parking lot to reach the monastery caves. Ticket price per adult is Rs 250 and there are 2 reclining Buddhas in their own caves. The torture scenes are quite interesting here too! Worth a quick stop on the drive from Kandy towards Dambulla if you have the time to spare

A holy and thrilling experience to see such a great temple carver into a rock. Need a little energy to climb the steep rock. Photography is prohibited inside the temple, but a must visit place inside Srilanka.

This is a temple about 30 kilo-metre North of Kandy, just beyond Matale on the Dambulla road . It's built on a hill, and not as well-known as the ones at Dambulla. Because of this, there are hardly any visitors, and you can wander around peacefully. The importance of this place is that it was where the teachings of the Budhha were first written down, after five hundred years of word of mouth teaching.  It is in a lovely setting. You can combine the visit of Aluvihara Rock temple with the Hindu temple in Matale. It is similar in style to Dambulla, although not as spectacular, this temple was worth visiting. The entry fee is not much and it is Rs 200 per head. There is no charges on parking. It is well worth a visit while passing for an interesting small hour. It is a bit of a walk up to the cave, but it is well worth it. It is a very interesting and peaceful place to wander around but very different from the normal temples. Monks accommodation looked far better and felt donations directed to the monastery is good. Very few tourists found there and this made the experience quite different from Dambulla with its crowds. On the way to Dambulla we stopped at Matale and were pleasantly surprised at seeing things there. It is a nice complex of cave temples after a small climb up some with stairs. There were Dambulla like caves only but much smaller and much quieter. No-one trying to sell you stuff in the premises. Some caves, shows devilish torture depictures and therefore not suitable for kids which is only in one. The view from the top is nice.  The location is very clean and gives such an amazing views. There were graphic images and statues.   If atmosphere is cool enough, can hike 1km up the hill to a location of the Buddha viewpoint. The climb is also not a lot. People around are friendly. Well worth a visit.
it's a religious place and please be calm and wear a fine dress ,some photos were not allowed inside
I stay meditate, learn Tipitaka writing on Ola leaves in this campus. Food was arrnaged to me by the Abbot and his associates
This is an ancient and a prominent  place of buddhist worship.   Many steps to climb, not for the faint hearted.   No footwear and suitable clothing covering knees and arms for both sexes.
As an experienced travelers, this sight is our most recommended Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka. About 270 stairs to get up there.
This is very famous temple in Matale. You can visit the temple in 1 hour (max) If you go early you can visit all without a rush due to low crowd.

Aluviharaya, a rock cave temple which has cave writings dating back to BCE. During the reign of king Walagambha, Tripitaka was written on ola (palm) leaves. That is first time, the Tripitaka was written. You can find more details on that on internet. There's museum which exhibits the traditional writing methods and tools used. Also you can see a preserved version of Tripitaka which was re-written in 1980s. As a rock cave temple it has a historical value because this is one of the earliest evidence of civilizations in upcountry Sri Lanka. (Not per-historic). There's small cliff which you can climb without much effort. At the top you can see surrounding mountains. Scenery is not that special. From Matale town, it is only 5 minutes drive towards Dambulla. Can use public transport as well. Plenty of buses are working. If you are a Buddhist pilgrim, it is an important place to worship because of the Tripitaka writings. If you are a history lover, think about the ancient technology used to write on Ola leaves. Those are the earliest evidences of proper writing systems in Asian history. If you are a linguist, think about the styles of Sinhala scripts, how well Sinhala language is structured. There is plenty of parking space available. Not crowded during weekdays. Crowds are gathering during poya days to observe sil. Also not much crowded during weekends. You need to have modest dress because this is a Buddhist religious place.

We were on our way to Sigirya when we decided to stop by this amazing place.  Famous for the fact that a few hundred years after the Buddha's death, his teachings were written down here by generations of monks (the whole lot was burned by the British centuries later), the temple is set among some huge boulders.  There are a couple of caves with some fantastic sculptures, masterpieces of Buddhist art.  In the museum, a nice man demonstrated how to write on palm leaves, which is how the monks did it back in the day.

A contrast to Dambulla and not as well known Well worth visiting for its great artwork and the location Much less touristic than Dambulla The pictures of the fate of wrongdoing in the second temple are brilliant

The rock temple at Dambulla was much better than I expected.Its a bit of a hard walk up the stairs and there is an entrance fee of 1500rp.Lots of monkeys everywhere at the top and a fee to have your shoes stored.The ground gets really hot on bare feet but they have small rugs to walk on.The temples are divided into rooms and depending on when you get there each room can be packed full and difficult to move around.Very humid inside too.The statues,frescoes and all the art work where’s great and much better than I expected.Well Worth the visit.On the way down you can visit the Golden Buddha statue at the bottom but that is a bit of a disappointment and tacky.

Fascinating Buddas and wall paintings on plaster on the walls of the cave. It was busy even though we went in the early morning to avoid the heat and crowds. The cool inside was very welcome. The sense of peace was a delight. Would recommend seeing.

Built by King Devanampiyatissa, the first Buddhist King of ancient Sri Lanka, the site is steeped in history as the place where the Tripitaka was transcribe in Pali on Ola leaf.  The cave paintings are unusually gruesome depictions of the consequences of sin, and the display of the 32 types of tortures used by ancient kings in the nearby rock museum may be disturbing to some youngsters.  The statue on the hill beyond the temple is accessible by another path.  There is a person providing examples of writing on ola leaf in the museum which is an interesting souvenir to have.
Nice visit to look at the small old temple in the stones. Beside is one of the Buddhist Hell gardens with sculptures.

Stayed at Dad's holiday home and walked here in about 30 minutes. It costs 250 Rupees entrance. Its really interesting. The highlight for me by far was walking up to the Golden Budha on the hill. Its a steep climb in parts and you need to be relatively fit. The initial stages are not very well signposted. I found myself in someone's garden at one point. They were clearly used to it and very lovely.  They showed me the way and helped me climb through their fence!!! I think you can get most of the way up in a Tuk Tuk if you want to avoid some of the climb....but the effort of walking makes the reward greater :) The view at the top is great and you can climb right up to the Budha. When I was there I was the only person  other than the prayer master guy. He invited me in, said a prayer, made a mark on my forehead and made me ring a big gold bell once - Im not entirely sure what it all meant - but it was rather lovely :)

It was so good to be back at this place after a year away. The Temple involves quite a climb and the rock gets very hot in the sun so early morning visits are best. It was built in the 3rd century BCE when the King built the Dagoba and planted the Bo tree. during his reign, Buddhism was introduced to the country and this Temple is the place where the Pali Canon was first written down in text on palm leaves. It has caves with ancient inscriptions plus wall and ceiling paintings and statues and images of the Lord Buddha.

The temple was built by king Devanampiyatissa in 3rd century B.C During reign of  king valagamba  in 1st century B.C . philosophical  Doctrine of buddhist  was written  by 500 monks  on ola leaves . during day time and night  time .  the villagers were looked light from temple during night  Therefore  they called as a aloka lena  [ cave of light]   after its called alu lena  finally  alu viharaya   . This is a cave temple  and monastery
It is in my home town and it is a very religious place built by king Walagamba. You still can observe ancient ruins built in that era. Also you can visit the Buddha Statue on the mountain behind.
Nice temple, but better to get to the temple either early morning or late evening cos the rock gets heated by the afternoon. Lot to climb, and to see.

If your visiting Sri Lanka and going from central towards North you should stop at this temple which is situated in Matale District. An ancient temple constructed ages ago by King Walagamba still maintained in a well manner. the temple has many ancient Buddha status, A painting that represents the Himalaya mountain range, and the four great rivers, The arch of Dragon, A painting and status that depicts hell punishments. Worth a visit once.

An Amazing temple, built under a large rock with cave shrines.. Well worth a visit, my favourite temple.. The Monkeys on the walk up the steps can be a nuisance if you have bought the lotus flower offerings..

We went there at the middle of our travel, mean that we already have done, dambulla, sigiriya, trincomalee and anuradhapura... so yes, this temple seems to be useless... 3 caves (small) with differents kind of torture that gods can do when you're a sinner... actually it could be interresting, but finally we didn't enjoy so much...

A must visit as part of SL ruins\historical sites. The hike to the caves is not too difficult. As with all places, early morning climb is recommended as it gets hotter after 10 AM. Carry your own food and water. The kings route from ticket counter is easier and quicker than the other hike. The paintings and sculptures are very impressive and reminds one of Ajantha caves.

We visited mid morning, when it was already warm and the caves just made matters slightly worse. We stayed in the lower bit and did not go up the hill to the Buddha, with hindsight the correct decision due to the heat, but I feel we have missed something. Make sure you visit the museum, the caretaker may do a example of a scroll that all the writings have been made on - we have a souvenir from our trip for a small tip. Worth a visit.

You can see this old temple after climbing up few stairs. Just before the entrance there is a place to leave your shoes (you have to go inside barefoot). If someone doesn't feel very comfortable with this, it is advisable to carry an extra pair of socks. The temple is located in the rocks. Inside the temple someone can see magnificent statues and frescos. No photos with people in front of Buddha statues are allowed, it is considered as lack of respect. Very close to the entrance you can see the holy tree. After seeing the temple you can enjoy the very nice view. It is a place worth visiting and it is recommended to have a guide with you.

This temple is 42km south if Dambulla on the road to Matale. There's a golden Buddha high above it on the hillside. Although newer than the one at Dambulla it has great significance to the people of SL and it's good to visit both and compare them as they are quite different in atmosphere. Visitor numbers here are much lower than at Dambulla so it's usually a peaceful spot to wander round and explore the caves with their Buddha images and wall painting which are entertaining if somewhat gruesome. I think it's a great spot to visit and if you are feeling really energetic you can ascend a kilometre further up the hill to the golden Buddha
It's very expensive for a steep walk up the side of a hill to see a cave  if you haven't seen a cave or the top of a hill this is for you Only so many temples in so many day until the fun runs out!

The dignity of Matale where a long time ago THRIPITAKAYA was written on. Still being worshipped by all Buddhists as well as others. A place must see and visit. The old photos (still preserved) are wanders of our ancestors.

This cave temple has two significant reasons for a traveler to visit. Firstly is an ancient temple dating back to pre-colonization of Sri Lanka and its architecture and the location and rock caves are unique in its own. Secondly this place was where Buddhist doctrine ( Thripitaka) which heather to conveyed from verbal form and generation of monks to the next, have been documented after a gathering of thousands of learned monks and consensus. it was documented in manuscripts of palm leaves.
This temple has several parts - lots of rock paintings and Buddha images to see. Don't forget to look up at the honeycombs hanging from the rock curve high overhead.

By good tradition you have to start paying at the entrance after climbing a dangerous stair, 250rp per person. If you think you can expect a similar experience as Dambulla cave  you are wrong. This are just a few small caves with mural decorations and a laying buddha. At the end to the left there is something awkward, a torture museum where a guy at the entrance tries to make you pay a second time. It is ridiculous. It is not worth your time.

This place is not far out of town; 3 kms, but I doubt people want to walk there. Here is what I did; tuk-tuk from Dad's for RS 150 to drop me off (8:30 AM), explore lower stupa then pay fee RS 250, drop off shoes, explore cave 1; nicest, cave 2; don't be a sinner or else and cave 3; not much there I could understand. Then I walked steps to upper smaller stupa that has a view of the hills & valley. Hey, how do I get up to the seated golden Buddha? With some directions AND my shoes on & a little help from an older lady I get to the path/road. It takes a hour to cane up to that Buddha (see photos), I stay +/- 20” and walking stick my way back down. I/you would have great views from up there folks. Even IF you do NOT go way up to the golden Buddha you should stop by Aluvihara IF you're going past, at least to see cave 1. FEW people were there. It's peaceful, man. There are HUGE boulders around this place. NICE!

The Aluvihara Temple in Matale is around 30km from Kandy town and is one of the many Buddhist Temples of Sri Lanka that are well worth visiting and which are of historic significance. The history of the place dates to the 3rd century BCE when the King built the dagoba and planted the bo tree. It is of importance because it is believed that the first Buddhist scriptures were documented here in Pali. The statues and carvings are exquisite. One needs to be reasonably fit for this place as there are steps to climb for accessing it.
Nice temple with several different buddha statues. you need to climb some stairs to see it all. When we were there it was not crowded with tourists.

We were driving from Kandy to Dambulla and the road goes through Matale. A quick stop made at the Aluvihara Temple which stands out like a beacon in an otherwise rural area. This is a historic Temple for Buddhism where one can observe the "Theravada" Preachings of Buddha. Heaven and Hell are depicted in terms of some of the caricatures. Plenty of steps to climb to enter the Caves and not an exercise for those not physically fit. I had already planned to visit The Dambulla Cave Temple the next day so this visit was brief.

One of the last place in Sri lanka where Pure "Theravada” Buddha Preaching were documented. This place is surrounded by green mountain ranges and forests, a good place for people who loves “Lord Buddha’s” memories and for hikers and nature lovers who like to adventure the rural srilankan hillside(please make sure to travel in the cooler climate times so you enjoy your self). And good site to glimpse the castigation of those who sinned, in hell, this temple contains few life size figurines of demons carrying out the punishments to those who passed on to the afterlife who had sin in there human life time,  something like “KAWATA-YAMUNE”. Tranquil temple to in the hill country .

The caves are at the top of a hill, lots of steps and not accessible yo wheelchair users and also wouldn't recommend to people with restricted mobility. Once you get to the top, you have to remove your shoes and then walk some more rock / cement before entering the caves. For some people, this can be very painful (maybe some feet, like mine,  aren't great for going barefoot!?!). Anyway, it's all worth it because of he beautiful statues and wall paintings. Tip: shove a pair (or extra pair) of fat, cotton socks, in your rucksack or bag. Once you remove your shoes you *can* wear socks, and this makes it much more bearable!

The ancient history of the place it self signifies the importance of the place where the Thripitaka was put in to text. The place was on a rock and best time to visit there is early morning when the atmosphere is cool. But even during the day time the caves are cool and refreshing. There is a place where the Underworld is displayed, which frankly was useless. A must visit if you are around the Matale district.

This temple complex is set at the top of a rocky mound. To get to the first shrine you need to climb about 20 steep steps. Inside you'll find a lovely reclining Buddha plus smaller statues. There is another shrine next to it and equally well decorated, plus a couple of smaller shrines as you make your way up the rocks and steps. Note the white Stupa on the way down. If you glance up towards the trees you can see another golden Buddha, which can be reached from this site but it's a bit of a trek.
A unique and an important place. Unique because it has a number of boulders and caves. Important temple for buddhists.

The education of the Buddhist monks writing / etching on leaves was more interesting than the caves themselves. A little bit run-down and obviously a heavy trail of tourists visit this location. Good views from the top of the temple. Rs. 250 entrance fee. Not good for wheelchairs or the elderly.

Sri Lanka has a special place in Theravada Buddhism because of the written scriptures stored in this temple. The original writings were destroyed by the British and new writings on ola leaves were done by the monks who had committed all these  sutras to memory. There is so much history to this temple and it is recommended that one goes with a guide. Temple also has impressive paintings and statues of the Buddha and his disciples. One has to remove shoes and hats and then climb hot cement/stone stairs to get to the top. It also gives a nice view of the area from the top. At the end of the tour one gets to see how writings are done on ola leaves, which is quite interesting. A little souvenir of the guests' names on a piece of ola leaves is also a nice touch. It is well worth a visit when passing through Matale to add to your knowledge of Theravada Buddhism.
It is a must place to visit as a buddhist, & worship. 2 km away from Matale town and easy access to the temple.

Aluvihara is the place where the Buddhist scripture was committed to writing by monks who lived in the caves at this location. Although it is a very significant place with beautiful Buddha statues and paintings and an amazing view, it does not attract too many tourists and therefore the place can be enjoyed quietly. there are some steps to climb and getting to the top is highly recommended as the view is amazing. Another interesting area is the wall paintings depicting the punishments one gets in hell for committing different types of sins. The well maintained temple contains a library with the Buddhist scripture written on Ola leaves. The original ones were destroyed by the British and what the library houses are the ones written recently.
After a climb you'll see some of the most beautiful buddha stone statues of Sri Lanka. The number of detailed statues is just amazing. The view from the top will be a sight you'll never forget.
On the road from Kandy to Dambulla. It is worth a stop! Quiet place with a nice view. The cave temples are well maintained.
It was very interesting to see the wall paintings of the Buddhist hell, for the sexual sinners. Something I would have never thought I would see. Fascinating.

I think that if you are passing this place, you should stop by  and savour that atmosphere, it is a very nice place and the paintings are very beautiful and they can have an effect on your children:-)
very  important place for Buddhist and a for tourists. It will taking a part of a The sacred temple is an archaeological site.

Located in the Matale district, in the town of Aluvihare. The cave temple is renowned for where the thripitakaya was written during the reign of king Walagamba. Buddhism was preserved in Sri Lanka as a result of the thripitakaya, being preserved in safety at this location. A peaceful and tranquil place that has great cultural significance.

A cave temple with ancient buildings. The place where Buddha dhamma which was being carried onto generations verbally was written into books. Crowdy on poya days and holidays. Less people on other days.
The temple has a unique historic value since this was the place where the holy Thripitakaya was written during era of king Walagamba
Definitely worth seeing if you are in the area.  I wouldn't drive 2 hours to see it but anything short of an hour's drive I would recommend to get your driver to drive you there!

The cave temples are definitely worth the visit, but be sure you have a knowledgable guide with you. We asked one of the cave employees to show us around, and he provided so much information that other groups left their guides to join ours. Beautiful and unique.

Unlike the Dambulla Rajamaha Viharaya, this temple is much smaller and much easier to reach. Entrance is 250lkr. Shoes storage is free :) The sign as usual says 'no photographs', but the person at the ticket booth said it was OK. Many pictures at this temple are around 'Hell' topic. A local worker joined us inside explaining about the temple (asked for a donation at the end) From the top there is a good view on the area and on the Golden Buddha located at some distance. The temple seems to be a working monastery with monks going around. We didn't see any other tourists during our visit.

Small cave temple with nice statues worth a stop if you are passing on the road to/from Kandy. The paintings depicting karmic results are interesting but not the outside badly made models doing the same thing nearby the cave temple and stupa, it's not worth it to make a donation to see that separate "exhibition". Views from the stupa are good but it is a long and tortuous walk around many narrow lanes to the Golden Buddha statue far up the hill, you might get lost. The main building shows you Buddhist sutras which are still copied using traditional methods in ola script and some are available for purchase

The Aluvihare Cave Temple has an important historical significance. It is believed that Aluvihare was the place where the Thripitaka (Buddhist scripture), which was passed down orally until then, was written down. The temple is built in the cave of a big rock, and there are beautiful painting and statues inside. A lot of locals come to worship here so might be crowded at times. You also need to get permission from the priests if you want to take pictures inside. It is also very easy to access since it is situated right on the main Kandy - Jaffna road (A9) , about 4km from Matale town.
While travelling to Anuradapura I went to Aluvihara. The place was so Beautiful and Peaceful. It was a rock cave temple.

Took some very good photos here as our group was lucky and had the place all to ourselves for quite a while. The children were,of course,immediately impressed with all the gory paintings in Technicolor depicting the king's punishments for not obeying the law of the land. Personally I prefered the golden Buddhas. This was already a monastery in I century a.D. and had a library that was destroyed in 1848 by the British troops during a revolt.
It is at a monastery and a school, at the bottom of a hill.  If you have been to the cave temple in Dambulla, there is no point visiting  this one unless you are free in the area.
Worth the stop if you pass on the road from Kandy to Sigiriya or Polonaruwa. The temple is really close to the main road. A peaceful place with statues and beautiful paints in the caves.

It's not expensive, although you do bizarrely have to pay again half way around, but it's only just over £1 so for interest level it's worth it. No-one goes into the museum but it is very interesting, not many exhibits but a fascinating look into the art of inscribing on palm leaves, demonstrating how the original and replacement Buddhist doctrines were created, naturally there is a minor contribution for which the resident guide is grateful! This is a very significant place for Buddhists and appreciating why is the least a visitor can do to show respect. To fully understand how these caves came about and why, it's worth taking 5 minutes to read up about it. The ceilings are beautifully painted and whilst one cave may depict peace and serenity, in the next the cave paintings are a true revelation into just how nasty the afterlife could be if you sinned; extremely graphic and gory depictions of torture and execution. When you think you have seen it all there's a very strange cave with models along the same line, which depicts what the king would do to sinners. It's a little odd compared to the other caves which are more connected to Buddha. This particular cave is not really suitable for small children. A worthwhile little visit.
Glad we had a brief stop here on the way to Dambulla. 250 rupees entrance fee. No crowds. Nice views and caves and gory paintings worth a look.

This is a small temple complex on our way to Kandy from Polonnaruwa. There is a series of small cave temples mostly with paintings which are in pretty good condition, as are the statues, which probably means they have been extensively reconstructed or are relatively new works. Consequently, they don’t look anywhere as old as they should be. There is an entry fee to the complex but unfortunately, some of the individual caves will demand additional payment as well. It’s not an essential stop, especially if you plan to visit the other main temple sites in Sri Lanka, but there were not many other tourists around, so it can be a good place for a  peaceful and contemplative hour.
These caves are interesting for a short visit. There is not much to be done around there but the painting and statues in the caves are impressive.
This had the feel of a disused theme park- shabby and slightly sad. Not much going on here and in a poor state of repair. Go to the Dumbulla Rock Caves and Golden Temple instead .

Many stories about the temple, But I really like the places where the Buddhist monks were residing and doing the writings. Many tourist miss this as they will be shown only the main caves with images and not the caves other side of the temple. Explore it.
Beautiful art work in a serene setting. Awe inspiring. Quite a climb to get there but worth the effort and the monkeys kept us entertained along the way.

The price of 1500 rupees per head was completely not justified. Once you have climbed the 360 steps they want another 25 rupees to look after your flip flops while you go inside the temple. The temple is poorly maintained and in my opinion very average with lots of standing/sitting/laying buddas in need of some TLC. The rock itself ,the paintings and the carving of the rock is quite impressive but by no means unique.
the temple Aluwihara is a amazing place with rock caves and its beautiful ancient wall paintings.very historical temple with srilanka's great history.

This is the main tourist attraction of Matale. This cave temple is an important place for Sri Lankan buddhist as writing of Thripitaka in Pali happened here at 1st century BC. It is situated 1km away from Matale town at A9 road. You can visit few caves at this temple. I think foreigners have to buy a ticket to enter some caves. ( What I don't agree to pay money to enter religious places ) Seru Gala is situated 1km behind Aluwihare Temple. Although it is not historicaly important but provide nice surrounding view. You can walk there from Aluwihare Temple. There is a newly built massive Buddha statue at Serugala.
this was one of our fisrt trips out in Sri Lanka and it was amazing. A bit of a walk from the enterance and quiet a steep hill. But when you get to the top its amazing.

Itz calm, peaceful and worth site to visit and have look..one of most well known temple among the buddhists but quite less visitors...just few km away from the mathale town...u have to climed few steps to reache the cave temple...several paintaings and murals can be seen in the caves which shows the life after death...locals two have to pay lkr 10/- &100/- to enter some caves...all types of visitors shoud well dressed prior to enter the temple premises..

Near the Matale town Kandy - Dambulla main road wit easy access. Not so touristic compare with some other ancient Buddhist temples under the Cultural trangle. But relate with a long and most highlight part of the first documentation of Buddhism in Srilanka. Aluvihare is one of the most important cultural sites in Sri Lanka.It was believed to be, Buddhist doctrines  were first recorded on Ola leaves after passing through orally, here in the 1st century BC, during the reign Anuradapura capital. When you visit this temple dont forget to see the Buddhict museum with "Tripitaka" document and to write your name in a peace Ola leave (ancient document) as memory.

This place is easy to find, it’s entrance lies on the main road to Dambulla. There are few caves with both lying and sitting golden Buddha. It’s very peaceful and beautiful with a nice view from the top.
Interesting and nice place to visit, impressive how the temple is built in the rocks. Just make sure not to buy flowers at the entrance

I visited this Temple area on my way from Habarana to Kandy. The entrance fee of 250SLR is very modest for this site as it doesn't really attract tourists. I went there because of the write-up in a travel guide and because a previous reviewer stated "most of the paintings in the temple represent various scenes with demons, including some extremely cruel torture scenes, which I've never seen in other, usually calm and tranquil Buddhist temples.". The paintings are scenes of grotesque torture that will be your fate if you don't follow the teachings of Buddha! Really bizarre and worth seeing if you're in to crazy art.

Aluvihara temple located much close to Matale town.it is one of the main Buddhist temples in Sri Lanka  and founded in 3rd century BC.this temple has done  very much contribution for Buddhism and it's protection. Due to bad climatic condition Buddhist monks had problems of memorising the Buddha's teachings so they(this temple) decided to write the Buddha's teachings in 1st century BC for future generations. What you  ane see now: Cave monastery with beautiful paintings. This is not a much touristic place and entrance ticket also very low.
This temple is a very old temple situated in mathale area. There are caves in this temple. While you visit there you can cover dambulla temple also

This is one of most important place for Buddhists in world wide and It has many significant importance. The teaching of Buddha's has been booked by this place and It was founded by King Devanampiyatissa, around 300 B.C.

Aluvihare temple is located few kilometers off Matale town , along Matale -Dambulla road. Waking through the Arc entrance, and climbing 47 stone carved steps, you can proceed up to the caves. One of the caves is historic as it is the cave Priest Buddhagosha wrote the doctrine of Buddha in pali with dedication. Another cave is the temple with caved statues of lord Buddha where large number of devotees call over to worship. climbing higher you reach the chaithya where you could have a panoramic view of the surrounding of blue hills around you. . At the temple museum you get the opportunity of experiencing the records of "ola leaf" where Ola leafs are seasoned and written on it with coal and oils extracted from "Kekuna" seeds. If you commence your journey from Kandy it takes only about one to one and half hours (25kms) to reach the location. Once visiting the Aluvihare temple there are many more attractions to view in Matale

This may be one of the most interesting Buddhist temples I've ever visited. It's situated on top of a rock and consists of several buildings and caves with a stupa on the very top of the rock with some steep steps leading to it. Most of the paintings in the temple represent various scenes with demons, including some extremely cruel torture scenes, which I've never seen in other, usually calm and tranquil Buddhist temples. The views from the stairs, and especially from the stupa are magnificent. And the brick gate with a bell in the middle of the temple gave me some additional colonial flavor of the place, though I have no idea if it is really a colonial influence, or a purely local construction. They require an entrance fee for the visit and some extra donation to visit one of the caves, but the place is absolutely worth it. I was surprised to see many other reviewers mentioning crowds, since when I was there the place was almost empty - probably 3-5 other visitors (mostly locals).
A brilliant trip and place to visit. The statues around are very atmospheric and there is lovely art work adorning the walls. Definately a place to see.

There are five ancient caves having statues of Buddha in various positions.though the caves are pretty but one has to climb a lot (around 250 stairs) to reach them.i didn't have a very good experience coz it was very tiring and not worth the effort both physically and monetarily for me

Those who form opinions, deriding art and antiquity that has survived the ages, seem to find themselves looking at it constantly in Sri Lanka. It was here before you arrived on Earth. It will still be here after you depart Earth. I've glazed over a couple of the review headings that are posted below. In short, go to Knox Berry Farm, Blackpool or EuroDisney if 'entertainment' is what you are after (if that's what entertainment is). Alternatively, sit at home and interrogate your navel. 'Aluvihara' has an important history and is a learning centre for student Monks.  Traditional 'Ola Leaf' manuscript writing, is taught here. 'Aluvihara' is not a specific trip on its own. Traveling north-south between Kandy and Sigiriya, one would stop at three specific places on the way south... 1. Dambulla Rock Temples 2. Nalanda 3. Aluvihara ... or of course, in reverse order if traveling north. There are a number of organic Ayurvedic farms within close proximity to 'Aluvihara', if you have the time to visit. Otherwise, please give generously to this very active Monastery.

It was fun to walk on all those rocks and sweat like never before but it doesn't help to have so many vendors around. One might want to sit on the way up to catch breath and drink water but these vendors won't leave you alone. For some reason, Sri Lankans don't understand the meaning of word NO. Paid some lkr1500+ and no helping hand. No details anywhere or brochures and the guide costs you around $20. You can haggle but it takes way too much energy on an already exhilarating hike up. Just go and see around, nothing magnificent inside to pay the fee. But if you have a guide then you might enjoy it more - can't say.
Cool and calm place with Buddhist environment. This is a ancient Buddhist temple with long history. Every one visit Sri Lanka must visit Aluvihara Rock Temple

First thing, find the ticket office when you get there as you can't buy one at the top. Luckily someone told us as it's not obvious where to get them. OK so you also need to have your legs covered so wear long trousers. When you get to the caves go to the far end and start there, that way you see the smallest first and save the best for last! Worth the climb but do take some water.
Ticket 250 rupees + want extra donation in two caves. How result, we don't visit in one of caves. Artworks inside caves is interesting, but low quality, in bad state and not ancient.

This was a smaller temple than Dambulla but we preferred it.  Small entrance fee of 250 Rs.  Reclining buddahs and roof paintings, but they seemed more vibrant as they were lighter, closer and easier to see.  There were people praying but it didn't feel intrusive just quite serene and tranquil.  The scenes of punishment with the devils were interesting, reminiscent of Dantes inferno.  Various rooms, and a good view of a large buddah and temple which have been built on a hill overlooking the valley.  There is a library, you can visit.  Also a naieve section with papier mache statues metering out punishment for various wrongdoings.  Overall, easily an hours visit.  We preferred this to Dambulla as not as touristy.

Up to a few years ago there were no charges to speak of but the government cottoned on to the huge money making potential of a 'captive audience' and bulldozed the prices up. Sri Lankans either go free or for Rs 60 (0.30 UKP For the money you don't even get a guide, printed material, or facilities. Some people we saw came up the mountain without tickets - perhaps chancing their arm - but were told that money could not be accepted and they would have to return to base and then come back. This is a succession of temples built into the rock. You need to start from the furthest and also the smallest and work forwards. it is difficult to be contemplative with tons of people milling around so early morning would be best. We left the site 'Buddhad Out'. There is a limit to the number of times you can be impressed by a single form(at). School parties are not helpful. They make a lot of noise - well they are kids. PS You will get pestered by sales people on the way up and also down. SEE MY OTHER REVIEWS FOR AN OVERVIEW OF SRI LANKA. Click on my user name to the left of this page and see the relevant entries.
If you're planning on visiting the Aluvihara Rock, it's worth climbing up the rock, a nice view of the Knuckles mountain range and nice breeze.

Much of this will be a highly personal and, thus, subjective call -- but I found the dripping, humid cave temples to be artistically and spiritually fascinating, more so than most other Sri Lankan temples I've seen on this trip. Went early, though, before the crowds, and that was undoubtedly part of the experience. Didn't mind the price of entrance this time around. Seeing the monkeys there was a plus.

Interesting site with kind of impressive caves but really overpriced. It's now 1500 rs !!! For a visit that last 20 minutes, no explanation at all touts everywhere selling Chinese made souvenirs. For that price, there is no toilet, and they make you pay for watching your shoes. Best thing to see is the sunset up the hill and you don't have to pay for that.

This takes about an hour in total & is well worth it. The entrance is stunning. You then walk up steps to get to the temple. The walk up the steps takes a bit of time, but is not too steep. When you get to the top you need to take your shoes off before entering. There are 5 temples and they are all stunning. Cost is about $15AUD per person.

When we arrived at the Golden Temple, we were a little put off by the kind of tacky looking museum entrance and cheesy monk statues. Our tuk tuk driver said it was the same as the Temple of the Tooth in Kandy and so we almost didn't take the time to go up to the temple proper. I am SO glad we didn't listen to our driver who, upon reflection, was just trying to get us to visit his "factory" instead in the hopes of getting a commission. Not only is the Rock Temple in Dambulla NOTHING like the Temple of the Tooth, but it was easily one of my favourite places that we visited in Sri Lanka. The temple itself is so fascinating, the way it's carved into the rock and how every inch of the cave is covered in beautiful paintings. I found it incredibly moving to be there, to the point where it brought me to tears. We took some time to meditate and were fortunate enough to witness a beautiful sunset from up on the hill. If you have a spiritual side, or an appreciation for world religions, this is a site not to be missed!

This cave temple is carved into an isolated rock outcrop 500ft high and a mile around the base.  The temple dates back to. Efirst century BC.  The caves of Dambulla sheltered the King Walagamba during his 4 years of exile from Anuadhapua.  There are a toal or five  temples .. In the first is a statue of Buddha in a reclining position 47 ft long. In the second cave, the finest and largest of them all, there are 150 life-size statues of Gods from the Buddhist religion along with numerous images of the Buddha himself.  The ceiling is also covered with frescoes which depict great events from the life of Lord Buddha.  Standing on the cave top one gets a panoramic view of the entire valley and on clear days the Sigiriya Fort is also visible.  The uphill climb is pretty daunting for senior citizens as I experienced and had to pause several times to catch my breadth but it was worthwhile having reached the summit.  Just breathtaking !

An amazing Buddhist Temple built into a mountain under a cliff overhang. This is one to see as it's so different in its design and placement. The inside is highly painted in Buddhist features and  Buddhas abound in each room.

Much better rock and cave temples around the country for a much more reasonable price (if not for free/donation). As it's a tourist attraction dragging in lots of coach parties the walk up has also attracted the opportunistic tat-sellers.

The climb up the granite stairs is stepp and takes about 15 minutes if you keep moving and don't stop to take photos with the many monkeys that will greet you along the way. Yes there is an admission charge as with all attractions in Sri Lanka it seems. Luckily it was not crowded during our visit and we could take the time to enjoy the view from the top and spend as much time as we wanted in each of the 5 caves. As with most attractions it helps if you read up on the history of the site first so as to fully appreiate how the carvings and painting came about in the caves. We skipped the museum part as it has a serperate fee and we had been told it was underwhelming. The enormous golden Buddha above the museum entrance is quite impressive and makes for good photo ops, although one should not pose with their back to the Buddha, try sidways instead out of respect.
For the cost of submission this attraction is underwhelming. The signing is not clear as to what attractions are on site, nor is the location and requirements to buy tickets.

Beautiful golden budha. Nice and clean site with an amazing view from the top. You can see the monkeys from really close walking up. (About 10-15 mins to the top) Caves were nice with the paintings and the statues but site was crowed. Entrance fee 1500 roupies. Not a must do for me but if you're in the area why not?

As most tourist attractions it was 1500 rupees per person for tourists (free for locals), but after a bit of a hard climb we made it to the top. View was sensational, especially watching the sunset. Caves themselves were also really good to see and appreciate. It was annoying having to pay for ppl to look after the shoes even after we'd already paid so much but that was the only downside. Also, if you do go for sunset bring a torch as they didn't turn on the lights for the steep walk back
Very good surroundings and well planned development is visible.Many pleasant local Buddhist Monks are an asset to the temple. The young monks are very courteous and helpful.

This is a nice rock temple! But you have to climb almost 120 stairs before reaching the temple. But you are able to see the nice mountain views when you are up there. Beware of the monkeys as they will snatched your belongings away. No shoes are allowed inside the temple. You have to leave your shoes at the shoerack and you have to pay about 25rupees. Its worth going it to see the different statues inside the cave. Do note that if you have hire your own tour guide, it is not allowed inside the temple. Your tour guide has to speak discreetly to you on the history of the rock cave.

Well it's pretty amazing to have a load of paintings and Buddhas at the top of a hill. In some cave-like caves.  So I did try to feel enthusiastic about it. I enjoyed the climb up since there is such a lot of good food in Sri Lanka I needed to walk. It would be shame not to see and it's not crowded.

Go enjoy the stories and different statues. And its for everyone whi is interested about history. So why not stop over on the way to Dambulla. Historic value is there in this cave temple too. Its different and worth the visit.

Well worth the visit, and extremely interesting. A small complex and easy access, with religous paintings inside the caves, some of the which are vivid depictions of Hell! Have your name written on a piece of traditional fabric, in Sinhalese.
its part of the Dambulla cave temples and its as good to visit as otheres... if you climbing all the way up you might as well check this ones out..
More cheap (only 250rs) smaller but not so touristic. Beauty of the caves like dambulla. Not so many steps to take as well

Visited at 07.30 on way to dambulla...just asked for donation...about 10 local visitors..lovely setting and in it's own way a better alternative to the kitsch of dambulla..monks accommodation looked far better and felt donation goes direct to monastary..if cool enough can hike 1km up hill to Buddha viewpoint. Combine with the Hindu temple in Matale.

Similar in style to Dambulla, although not as spectacular, this temple was worth visiting for the experience of having very few tourists. We were certainly the only western tourists at the time we visited, and this made the experience quite different from Dambulla with its crowds. One thing I did not quite expect was the graphic images and statues, one cave in particular I would not recommend for kids, we had our 2 and 4 year olds with us, and we had to cover their eyes as we walked through, they were really quite graphic! Apart from this it was still worth a pleasant ramble through the area. It's not part of most tour routes, we had to ask to go there. I'm not sure the entry price but I believe very cheap.

On the way to dambulla we stopped at Matale and were pleasantly surprised. A nice complex of cave temples after a small climb up some stairs. Dambulla like caves only smaller and much quieter. No hasslers trying to sell you stuff. Worth a visit while passing for interesting small hour. Only drawback is that some caves show devilish toture depictures.

Don't get me wrong, it is interesting, but the both the frescos, whilst unusual, and the reclining Buddhas did not seem terrible ancient to me. The view from the top is nice. The museum nothing to write home about.
Bit of a walk up to the cave, but well worth it, very interesting and peaceful place to wander around. The cave's are cool and full of a variety of Buddha's. Very different from the normal temple

Went here and was pleased to not get changed an extortionate price to get in (just rs200) and to be left alone to wander for a bit while there. They're was even a wedding taking place at the time too. Don't miss it.
Loved the cave temple s . Very clean and such amazing views .the climb is also not a lot .Very friendly people .

Great views, interesting caves, although not as good as Dambulla, didn't like being spivved for extra cash for a gimmicky side show of torture models or a "papyrus" book mark in the museum - steer clear of these unwanted additions to your visit.
Walk up the steps take your time and soak in the atmosphere, because you'll be glad you did just to see and hear the amazing sights and sounds - Well worth a visit

This is a temple about 30 kilometres noth of Kandy, just beyond Matale. It's built on a hill, and not as well known as the ones at Dambulla. Because of this, there are hardly any visitors, and you can wander around peacefully without guards hustling you. The cave temples have some nice carved statues and wall murals, but the importance of this place is that it was where the teachings of the Budhha were first written down, after five hundred years of word of mouth teaching. Unfortunately, the library was mostly destroyed in the nineteenth century when the British were suppressing a rebellion. This wonderful place did not require us to buy tickets or pay anything for parking the car.

Aluvihara in Mathale is a well worth a visit if you are passing by. The location is famous for its cultural value as the famous Thripitakaya was translated in this location. The temple in the rock cave is an amazing site to see.
Visiting Dambulla, I had the opportunity to visit this ancient Temple. This has a very long histry, as the Buddhist Tripitakaya has been inscribed. Very Calming and relaxing

The five caves are accessed by walking up around 300 steps, the walk is manageable by most and you are free to go at your own pace. The view from the top of the surrounding area is impressive and the caves themselves are fairly impressive however I have seen a lot of Buddhist temples and they are all very similar these are no more impressive than most. Few things to note - make sure you buy a ticket prior to going up the steps, take water as surprisingly there is none available to buy at the grounds, cover your knees and shoulders otherwise you will not be allowed to enter the caves this includes both men and women. At the top of the steps before entering the caves you will be told to leave your shoes for a charge and he will say you are not allowed to carry them however we just put them in our bag and had no problem with this also there is some walking to do once you remove your shoes so may be handy to take socks as the ground is really hot and burnt our feet!! Lots of monkeys around who aren't phased by humans but also caused no problems during our visit.

An incredible series of monastic caves among the rocks.  The first cave had a 30 foot long reclining Buddha and colorful painted lotus-pattern murals on the ceiling. Another had murals of the punishment for sins in hell – very graphic, and somewhat disturbing.  Took stairs to the top of the rock bluff w/ beautiful view and a group of 5 playful monkeys, including a couple babies.  Very spiritual place, but caves were not very well let, so was dificult to see. Liked that it was much more intimate and less crowded than the Dambulla caves, but if you only have time to do one, I'd definitely do Dambulla - so impressive.
very interesting place to visit  - calm and peaceful  a working holy place not just a tourist place to visit - good photo opportunity -

This site is well worth visiting with lots of sculptures and paintings in the caves. A warning if walking is an issue. There are a lot of steps up to the caves and this could be hard work. Take it slowly and it is worth the effort.

We stopped at the Aluvihara Rock Cave Temple on our way from Sigiriya via Dambulla to Kandy. It is smaller and much quieter than Dambulla, and no long climb to reach it. (We had done enough climbing after visiting the other sites earlier in the day.) There is a monastery within the site, which gives you the sense it is not only a museum but actually a holy place in use. It is well worth a stop.

Really enjoyed these caves which are one of the most significant sites for Budhism. Lots of steps to get up to the caves. Much quieter than Dambulla Rock Caves so you have them to yourself, also cheaper only 1000 rupees.

Aluvihara is less of a tourist destination than Dambulla rock caves, although it's definitely worth a brief stop in to see the temples. They are a great way to learn some of the hindu/buddhist beliefs and although some of the motifs are quite graphic, it's an interesting place to wander.

We stopped here and were not expecting much considering how much we liked the Dambulla caves. But what an unexpected surprise! The place seems to be less famous and so to light up the caves we were given a portable fluorescent lamp. But the caves were really worth it and we were especially impressed by the painting depicting the Maras (demons) inflicting their terror. The place was very well maintained for a very reasonable entry ticket. Worth a visit!

This was one of 3 temples we visited on the road from Kandy to Dambulla. There was a service taking place in the gardens but we walked through and up to the rock caves were you see what is apparently a Buddhist version of hell. It certainly not somewhere I would want to end up. Its an interesting place with views up to another Buddha statue in the hills. Its well worth a visit.
The day of our visit there were wasps so we never did the climb but the area in itself is truly interesting

It's a nice little train ride from Kandy (1 1/2 hours each way). And, it's nice being where the Tipitaka was written into Pali.  But the caves/scenes are nothing spectacular or essential.  There are some lifesize 'sinners'  made of plaster (I think) behind cages and a few more original/older wall murals.  It was annoying that the 'guardians' expected extra tips/donations to go inside each cave site - the only place I experienced that in Sri Lanka.  I didn't go to Dambulla, but I'm sure it's a much more rewarding experience (and I've been through temples/caves throughout SE Asia).

Many people confuse this with cave temple. But these 2 are different. as far as i remember from my study 'Aluvihara; means temple of ash. alu means ash. according to mythology there was a giant living at this place once upon a time. he used 3 rocks as his cooking pot. so there was ash.Later monks used them as shelter. Still there are rocks. u have to climb up. u can imagine those was giant's cooking pot! we were there at "poya' means full moon. many people came for prayer wearing white dresses. we joined them, they dont mind. there is some peculiar cartoonish pics on wall describing punishments of sinners afterlife. i was wondering as far as i know Buddhism is not about crime and punishment. there is no hell or haven in Buddhism. i was confused and there was not to explain. from the the top u can enjoy the scenic beauty and a statue of Buddha from another hill which is very far. we really appreciated local cone ice cream at the foot of the rock after get down.
It was very interesting to see the wall paintings of the Buddhist hell, for the sexual sinners. Something I would have never thought I would see. Fascinating.

On the road from Kandy to Dambulla, just 1,5 km past Matale, there is this weird temple on the left side of the road. The temple complex and statues are not very different from many others in Sri Lanka, but the paintings in one of the rock temples are! Her the buddhist hell is depicted in a very graphic way. Better be a devout buddhist, because things that happen to you when in buddhist hell are beyond description, but very clear in the numerous murals. You are not supposed to take pictures, but it is worth taking the risk. It is a nice stop on the road north, and the ice cream sold on the parking is good at only 50 rupees.
